For over a year now, Kadiatu has been selling palm oil (the most popular cooking oil), salt, pepper, margi (used to give sauce a sweet taste), tomatoes, etc. With this loan, she will buy palm oil, salt, pepper, margi, tomatoes, etc., at wholesale to add to her business.

(Also included in the photo is loan officer Edward A. Ndoinjeh, handing over the loan to the borrowers.)

loans.use: to buy palm oil, salt, pepper, margi, tomatoes, etc., at wholesale to add to her business.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Tayorma Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the Tayorma group from Koidu, a city in eastern Sierra Leone. They are petty businesswomen who have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva.org in order to seek a loan of 500,000 Sierra Leonean Leones (SLL) for each member in the group. With this loan, they will be able to add more goods to their businesses, attract more customers, make more sales and profit, and consequently improve their living conditions. 
Dora is the leader of this group of entrepreneurs. She was born in eastern Sierra Leone. She is married to a farmer and has eight children. Dora has been a businesswoman for ten years now. She produces and sells soaps. With her share of this loan, she will buy caustic soda, palm-oil, and other supplies for the production of a larger quantity of soaps for sale. 

(Also included in the photo is loan officer Edward A. Ndoinjeh, handing over the loan to the borrowers).

loans.use: to buy caustic soda, palm-oil, and other supplies for the production of a larger quantity of soaps for sale

loans.name: Shiiter

texts.en: Shiiter is a 41-year-old man who lives with his wife and three children in the central province of Mongolia. His wife is employed. Two of his children go to secondary schools. He started a freight transportation business in 201. He owns a small truck that he uses to deliver sacks of coal into the city. He has been supporting his family members with the business income. Shiiter is a clever man who says that, "I would like to increase the business activities by repairing my truck. Because it has been broken down, it needs to be repaired in order to stabilize the business. I am planning to develop the business, not stop it." The total amount he is requesting is 3,500,000 MNT to buy spare parts for the truck.

loans.use: to buy spare parts for the truck

loans.name: Josphat

texts.en:
Josphat is 30 years old and married. He is a father of three children aged ten, seven and one. He owns a butcher shop, where he sells cow and goat meat, and he has been in the business for three years, earning a monthly income of KES 20,000.  
He is servicing his first loan of KES 20,000 from KADET and intends to purchase a cow and goats for slaughter. The anticipated profits will be put back into the business. He hopes to expand his business to other locations.

loans.use: to purchase a cow and goats for slaughter

loans.name: Suyunbubu

texts.ru:
Суюнбубу 55 лет, замужем, воспитала 7 детей. Суюнбубу в качестве основного дохода для своей семьи, с 1978 года занимается животноводством, начав этот бизнес с покупки коровы. На сегодняшний  день в хозяйстве Суюнбубу  имеется 1 дойная корова, 5 лошадей и 20 овец. Ежемесячный доход с продажи  молочных продуктов составляет 3,500 сом (KGS) в месяц. 
В целях дальнейшего развития своего бизнеса, Суюнбубу обратилась в компанию «Бай –Тушум и Партнеры» за кредитом в сумме 50,000 сом (KGS)  на покупку дойной коровы для увеличения продаж молока.  Доходы от кредита Суюнбубу планирует вложить в дальнейшее увеличение хозяйства.
texts.en:
Suyunbubu is 55 years old, she is married and has raised seven children. Suyunbubu started her business as a main source of income for her family and since 1978 she has been engaged in animal husbandry which she started with the purchase of a cow. Today Suyunbubu's livestock has one milk cow, five horses and twenty sheep. Her monthly income from the sale of dairy products is 3,500 som (KGS).

With the goal to further grow her business Suyunbubu has come to Bai Tushum and Partners for a loan in the amount of 50,000 KGS to buy a milk cow to increase milk sales. Suyunbubu plans to invest the income from the loan into further increase of her livestock.

loans.use: to purchase a cow.

loans.name: Anielka Karina

texts.es:
La joven Anielka Karina, como hija responsable y abnegada piensa en el futuro y mejorarle cada día la vivienda a su madre.
Labora como profesora de secundaria desde hace 4 años.
Una de las necesidades que tiene en este momento es mejorar la habitación de la vivienda donde habita por lo que se acercó por primera vez a Ceprodel con el objetivo de que le otorgaran un crédito para la compra de cemento, hierro, arena, puerta y pago de mano de obra.
Confía en Dios y pone la esperanza en esta Institución para que le apoye con este sueño de mejorar su vivienda y salir adelante ya que estos créditos son de gran ayuda para los asalariados y personas de bajo recursos.
texts.en:
This young woman, Anielka Karina, is a responsible and devoted daughter who thinks about the future and wants to improve her mothers home. She has been working as a high school teacher for 4 years.

Anielka Karina needs to improve the bedroom of the house where she lives, and so she approached Ceprodel for the first time to request a loan for the purchase of cement, iron, sand, a door and payment of construction labor.

She trusts in God and hopes that the institution will support her in her dream of improving their house and moving forward, because these loans are helpful for salaried workers and low-income people.

loans.use: to purchase cement, iron, sand, a door and payment of construction labor.

loans.name: Gissela Alexandra

texts.es:
EL Banco Divino Niño Jesús se reúne cada quince días en el Cantón Jipijapa, cantón conocido con el nombre de la sultana del café por los extensos cultivos de café el cual tiene un sabor incomparable, por su gastronomía y por la calidez de su gente.
 
En este lugar vive la señora Gissela, tiene 24 años de edad y mantiene una relación de unión libre pero aun no tiene hijos. El marido es comerciante.
 
Ella y su esposo se dedican a la cría de pollos y aves de corral, tienen una granja en la cual por temporadas meten hasta  300 pollos, los mismos que los crían  por espacio de tres meses y que luego los entregan a comerciantes, o los llevan a entregar a tiendas de la localidad, nos cuenta que llevan tres años dedicados a este negocio y les va muy bien, la mejor temporada es la del mes diciembre en estas fechas venden hasta 500 pollos. 

Este crédito es para comprar pollos, alimentos y medicinas para los mismos para que tengan un buen desarrollo. Lleva dos años en el Banco Comunal y le gusta porque gracias a los créditos construyeron un galpón más grande y pudieron aumentar su producción.
 
Sus sueños son comprar un carro para vender otras ciudades y aumentar más su negocio.
texts.en:
The Communal Bank "Divino Niño Jesús" (Divine Christ Child) meets every 15 days in the canton of Jipijapa, which is known by its nickname "The Sultana of Coffee" because of its extensive coffee crop that has an incomparable flavor. This area is also known for its food and the warmth of its people.

Sra. Gissela lives in this place. She is 24 years old, in a common-law relationship, and has no children. Her husband is a merchant.

She and her husband raise chickens and other poultry. They currently have a farm on which they can raise up to 300 chickens at a time. The birds are raised in that space for a period of three months before being sold to merchants or delivered to local stores. Gissela says that she has been in this business for three years and has done very well. Her best season is the month of December when she can sell up to 500 chickens.

This loan will be used to buy chickens, feed, and medicines so that the birds can develop properly. Gissela has been with her Communal Bank for two years and enjoys being a member because the loans helped her to build a large chicken coop so that she could increase her production. Her dreams are to buy a car so that she can sell in other cities and to increase her business even more.

loans.use: to buy chickens, poultry feed, and medicines.

loans.name: Jesucristo

texts.es: Jesucristo de 58 años de edad,  vive con su cónyuge y tiene dos hijos en las edades de 28 y 33 años, en el municipio de Puerto Colombia, un lugar muy cerca al mar, a 20 minutos de la ciudad de Barranquilla. Allí tiene una remontadora de calzado de la cual genera ingresos para apoyar el sustento de su hogar. El tiene su pequeño ambulante taller que rueda desde su vivienda hasta la plaza principal del pueblo, donde se ubica y es muy reconocido por todos los pobladores de Puerto Colombia. En su negocio presta el servicio de reparación de toda clase de calzado; él cambia suelas, arregla tacones, hace tinturado a la capellada de los zapatos y también hace costuras de los mismos ocasionalmente. Este oficio lo aprendió desde muy joven con un señor en a plaza de San Nicolás de la ciudad de Barranquilla. Con su trabajo provee lo necesario para vivir dignamente. En la actualidad está aplicando a un credikiva, con el que comprará materiales e insumos que usa a diario, como suelas, plantillas, caucho y goma al por mayor, para ganar descuentos por la cantidad y tener un stock,  que le permita atender más oportunamente a su clientela. En su buen humor caribeño Jesucristo se considera que con su nombre no tiene tocayo (una palabra usada para referirse una persona respecto de otra que posee el mismo nombre) y dice que entre risas y bromas que le presten con confianza porque “Jesucristo no le queda mal a nadie“. Su credikiva es el primer financiamiento que le hace a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, porque tiene muchos sueños como el de abrir un local publico y organizar mejor su negocio y con su crédito empezará el camino a sus metas, porque como el dice tiene poca formación académica pero está graduado en la universidad de la vida.
texts.en:
58-year-old Jesucristo lives with his wife and two children, aged 28 and 33, in the town of Puerto Colombia. The town is very near the sea, 20 minutes from the city of Barranquilla. There, he has a shoe cobbling business which generates revenue to support his family and household. He has a small travelling workshop that he rolls from his house to the main square where he works, and he is recognized by all the people of Puerto Colombia. 

Jesucristo provides repair services for all kinds of footwear - he changes soles, fixes heels, dyes the uppers of the shoes and occasionally stitches them. He learned this trade at a young age, from a gentleman in St. Nicholas square in Barranquilla. His work provides him with enough income to live in dignity. 

Jesucristo is currently applying for this loan, with which he will purchase materials and supplies for everyday use such as soles, insoles, rubber and shoe uppers. He will purchase wholesale to benefit from bulk discounts and build up a stock, which will allow him to serve his customers in a more timely manner. 

In good humor, Jesucristo considers that with his name, he has no 'Tocayo'  (a word used to refer to another person that has the same name), and between laughter and jokes he says that people lend to him with confidence because "Jesus Christ did not hurt anyone."

This loan is the first loan that he has taken with the Mario Santo Domingo Foundation, because he has many dreams as opening his own public premises. He wants to improve the organization of his business, and this loan will begin the path to his goals. Jesucristo says that he has little academic training, but he is a graduate of university life.

loans.use: to purchase materials and supplies for everyday use such as soles, insoles, rubber and shoe uppers in bulk.

loans.name: Mercedes Stella

texts.es:
EL Banco Divino Niño Jesús se reúne cada quince días en el Cantón Jipijapa, cantón conocido con el nombre de la sultana del café por los extensos cultivos de café el cual tiene un sabor incomparable, por su gastronomía y por la calidez de su gente.
 
Aquí conocimos a la señora Mercedes,  tiene 41 años de edad, es madre soltera de  dos hijos de 20 y 14 años de edad, los mismos que  estudian en universidad y colegio, los cuales representan muchos gastos para nuestra amiga. Lleva 6 años en el Banco Comunal y le gusta porque gracias a los créditos empezó su negocio y ha podido salir adelante sola con sus hijos.

Ella con la intención de ganarse la vida  y con esto poder salir adelante junto con sus hijos  se dedica al comercio, vende ropa de todo tipo, zapatos, sabanas, toallas, toldos, entre otros productos, nos cuenta que vende lo que sea con tal de ganar algo y que a sus hijos nunca les falte nada,  su forma de  venta es puerta a puerta y  también vende en su  casa donde tiene dos  vitrinas, sus hijos le ayudan cuando están desocupados. Trabaja todos los días más que todos en las mañanas, ella  deja a crédito a sus clientes  y cobra cada 8 días. Su mercadería  la va a comprar a  Guayaquil o a Cuenca cada vez que necesita. Tiene 6 años que se dedica a esta actividad y gracias a esto ha salido adelante.

Este crédito lo va emplear en comprar más mercadería como: ropa, sábanas, toldos, zapatos entre otras cosas.
 
Su sueño es ver que sus hijos terminen sus estudios y sean buenos profesionales.
texts.en:
The Divino Niño Jesús (Divine Child Jesus) Communal Bank meets every 15 days in Jipijapa canton, which is known by the name "The Sultana of Coffee" due to its extensive cultivation of a coffee with an incomparable flavor. The canton is also known for its gastronomy and for the warmth of its people.

This is where we meet Ms. Mercedes. She is 41 years old and the single mother of two children aged 20 and 14 years old. They are studying in college and high school, respectively, which presents many expenses for our friend. She has been in the Communal Bank for six years and she enjoys it because thanks to the loans, she started her business and has been able to get herself and her children ahead on her own.

She got involved in commerce with the intention of making a living so that she and her children could carry on. She sells all types of clothing, shoes, sheets, towels, and awnings, among other products. She tells us that she sells what she does in order to earn some, and that her children never want for anything. Her manner of sales is door-to-door, although she also sells at her home, where she has two display cases. Her children help her when they are not busy. She works every day, mostly in the mornings. She sells to her customers on credit and bills them every eight days. She goes to buy her merchandise in Guayaquil or Cuenca whenever she needs to. She has been in this business for six years and has gotten ahead thanks to it.

This loan is going to be used to buy more merchandise, such as clothing, sheets, awnings, shoes, and other things.

Her dream is to see to it that her children finish their studies and become successful professionals.

loans.use: to buy clothing, sheets, awnings, shoes, etc.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy fabric remnants in bulk.

loans.name: Millicent

texts.en:
Millicent is a 31-year-old single lady with one child. She has a business which retails cosmetics, mobile phones and provides M-pesa (a mobile phone-based money transfer service). Millicent has been in this business for seven years and earns a monthly income of KES 20,000.  

This will be her first loan with KADET LTD and she plans to use the entire loan to increase her M-pesa float. With the profits, she will buy a plot of land. In future, she wants to build her house.

loans.use: to increase her M-pesa float

loans.name: Na God Dae Gee Group

texts.en:
The members of the “Na God Dae Gee” group from Koidu, a city in eastern Sierra Leone, are all local entrepreneurs who have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva.org, to each apply for a loan of 500,000 Sierra Leonean Leones (SLL). With the help of this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and consequently improve their living conditions. 

Adama, aged 37, is the leader of this group. She is married to a driver and they have three children who attend primary and secondary schools. Adama has been a businesswoman for many years now: she sells market food – rice, fish, pepper, salt, palm oil, etc. With her share of this loan, she is going to buy rice, fish, pepper, salt, palm oil, etc. at wholesale prices to add to her current stock. 

 (Also included in the photo is loan officer, Edward A Ndoinjeh, handing over the loan to the borrowers).

loans.use: to buy rice, fish, pepper, salt, palm oil, etc. at wholesale prices to add to her current stock.

loans.name: Hawa

texts.en:
Meet 50-year-old Hawa from Waterloo, a neighborhood in Freetown. She is a widow and has three children between the ages of 16 and 30. One of her children is currently attending school. In 2004, Hawa established her general merchandise business. She began her business because she wanted to have a permanent source of income to support her family. She works seven days per week and 10 hours a day and earns about Le 1,200,000 every month from this business. Hawa describes her major problems as inadequate electricity supply and rapid increase in transportation costs.

She would like a loan of Le 5,000,000 which she needs so she can buy different kinds of drinks and water packets for her business. Hawa hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profit to approximately Le 500,000. In the future, Hawa plans to open her business in other areas within her township. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy different kinds of drinks and water packets.

loans.name: Juan Bautista

texts.es: Juan con su anterior  credikiva compró cera y una estampadora, para adecuar una vez más sus panales. Así mismo compró implementos para fabricarlos, envases y etiquetas para comercializar su dulce miel. En la actualidad está aplicando a un credikiva, con el que comprará una maquina centrifugadora, y más cera estampada e implementos para nuevos paneles. Su mensaje a los financiadores de Kiva es el siguiente: “Estoy muy agradecido por el gran apoyo recibido por ustedes y por la oportunidad que me han dado de que mi negocio sea conocido por otros, así mismo por la capacitación y asesoría de la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo.“
texts.en:
With his previous Kiva loan, Juan bought wax and honeycomb foundation so that he could produce more honeycomb panels. He also purchased equipment for processing, packaging, and labeling the sweet honey that he sells. Juan is currently applying for a Kiva loan so that he can buy a centrifugal machine (for extracting honey) and more honeycomb foundation and tools for making new panels.

His message to the Kiva lenders is as follows: "I am extremely grateful for the overwhelming support you have given me. This opportunity has given people the chance to become familiar with my business. I also appreciate the training and advice from Fundación Mario Santo Domingo."

loans.use: to buy a centrifugal machine for extracting honey, honeycomb foundation, and tools for producing more honeycomb panels.

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter is a businessman who runs a spare parts shop.  He has been operating his business in the town centre.  This is a good strategic location  because he gets many customers. Since he joined Faulu Kenya, he has expanded his business. Peter has also been trained in financial management. This has helped him to save his money.

Peter dreams of opening a wholesale business in the future.  He needs a loan of 80,000 Kenya shillings to buy motor vehicle spare parts.

loans.use: To buy motor vehicle spare parts.

loans.name: Eddah

texts.en:
Eddah is a 51-year-old single woman with four children. She operates a grocery store where she sells both vegetables and cereals. Eddah has been in this business for 30 years and earns a monthly income of 15,000 shillings. 

This will be her first loan with KADET LTD and she plans to use the entire loan to buy more rice. With the profits, she will expand the business. In future, she wants to complete her residential house.

loans.use: to buy more rice

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is 48 years old, married to Michael, and together they have two school-going children. She rears sheep and later sells them, mostly to other traders in the market as well as to hotels at a profit.

Margaret learnt about KADET during one of their marketing events in the area. This will be her first loan and she plans to use the loan amount of 20,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) to buy more sheep to rear and later sell at a profit.

In the future, Margaret hopes to expand her business and to earn more income hence improving her family's living standards.

loans.use: To buy more sheep

loans.name: Faith Sisters Group

texts.en:
In the photo are members of the “Faith Sisters” group. They are small-scale businesswomen based in Koidu, a city in eastern Sierra Leone. This is the first loan that these entrepreneurs have accessed from SMT/Kiva lenders. With this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more profit and consequently improve their standard of living. 

The leader of this group is Mariama. Mariama is aged 36; she was born in Kono where she is currently residing with her husband and two children. Her husband is a businessman and her children are attending primary and secondary schools. For many years now, Mariama has been selling shoes. With this loan, she will buy shoes at wholesale prices to add to her business.

(Also included in the photo is loan officer, Edward A Ndoinjeh, handing over the loan to the borrowers.)

loans.use: to buy shoes at wholesale prices to add to her business

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia is 40 years old. She is widowed with three children. She sells charcoal and vegetables and has been in the business for the past one year.

This is her first loan from KADET LTD. She was brought to KADET LTD by a staff member. She will use the loan amount to purchase more stock of charcoal and vegetables for resale.

She hopes to get a permanent place to do her business.

loans.use: to purchase more stock of charcoal and vegetables for resale.

loans.name: Winfred

texts.en:
Winfred is a 32-year-old married woman with four children. She sells mobile phones/ electronics, has been in this business for five years and earns a monthly income of 100,000 shillings. 

This will be her first loan from KADET LTD: she plans to use the entire loan to buy more stock and to open an M-Pesa business (a mobile phone-based money transfer service). With the profits, she will buy a plot of land. She would like to have a good future.

loans.use: to buy more stock and to open an M-Pesa business

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice is 27 years old, married and blessed with a one-year-old child. She has been operating a tailoring business for five years and employs two people in her business. Through Faulu Kenya, Alice has learnt how to save her money because she has been trained in financial management.

Alice hopes to open a dressmaking college in the future. She has requested a loan of 80,000 Kenyan shillings to buy more fabric.

loans.use: To buy more fabric

loans.name: Luciah

texts.en:
Luciah is 69 years old. She is married to Warige and all their children are adults: none are dependent on them. She is a farmer and has been in the business for the past 32 years.

This is her first loan after she was introduced to KADET by a KADET staff member. She will use the loan amount to purchase fertilizer and seedlings and to pay laborers to assist her with planting.

She hopes to build and own rental houses in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer and seedlings and to pay laborers to assist with planting

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter is 51 years old and is married with four children. He operates a restaurant and has been in the business for the past three years.

This is his first loan from KADET LTD. Peter was introduced to KADET LTD by a staff member. He will use the loan amount to purchase wheat flour, cooking fat, sugar and drinks for use in the restaurant.

He hopes to open a bigger restaurant in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase wheat flour, cooking fat, sugar and drinks.

loans.name: Timothy

texts.en:
Timothy is 29 years old, married and blessed with a three-year-old child. He sells secondhand clothes so as to earn a living.  He has employed two people to assist him in the business. He also operates a retail shop so as to supplement his income. Through Faulu Kenya, he has been trained in financial management. This has helped him to budget well in his business.

Timothy hopes to expand his business and employ more people. He needs a loan of 50,000 Kenya shillings to add to his stock of clothes.

loans.use: To add to his stock of clothes

loans.name: Paul

texts.en:
Paul is 43 years old and married with three children.  To earn a living, he runs a tailoring business. He has been operating this business for over 10 years.  He has employed two people to assist him in his tasks. Besides tailoring, he does poultry farming to supplement his income.

Paul has experienced upward growth in his business since he joined Faulu Kenya.  This is because he has been trained in business management.   Paul hopes to open other outlets of his business in the future. He has requested a loan of 60,000 Kenyan shillings to buy a sewing machine and fabric.

loans.use: To buy a sewing machine and fabric

loans.name: Patrick

texts.en:
Patrick is 42 years old. He is married to Mary and together they have four children. He buys and sells wool and has been in this business for the past four years.

This is his first loan from KADET LTD. He was introduced to KADET LTD by staff. Patrick will use the loan amount to purchase more stock of wool for resale in his business.

He hopes to be a renowned wool dealer in his area.

loans.use: to purchase more stock of wool for resale.

loans.name: Neveen

texts.en:
Neveen is 26 years old and a married woman, a mother of three children. She lives in Al Hashmi, Jordan.

Neveen is looking to have a loan of 500 JDs so she can buy and sell clothes so her social and economic status will improve.

Neveen is under 30 years old, so her loan is considered as a youth loan.

loans.use: to buy and sell clothes

loans.name: Rawan

texts.en:
Rawan is 28 years old and a married woman. She lives in Al Karak, Jordan.

Rawan is looking to have a loan of 500 JDs so she can pave the floor of her house.

Rawan is under 30 years old so her loan is considered a youth loan.

loans.use: to pave the floor of her house

loans.name: Miriam Antonia

texts.es:
Miriam, administra una pupuseria, vive con su esposo, la casa es familiar, tienen 4 hijos de 14, 11, 8 y 4 años de edad, desde hace ocho meses ha iniciado con la venta de pupusas, pues inicialmente solo administraba una tienda.
Ella quiere realizar una inversión en el negocio, comprándose maíz, aceite, condimentos, quesillo, y otros materiales que son necesarios para realizar la venta, con este préstamo estarán mejorando su nivel de ventas.
Su objetivo es tener un negocio más grande, con más clientela y que le provea mayores ganancias.
texts.en:
Miriam manages a "pupuseria" (a restaurant that serves "pupusas"). She lives in the family home with her husband and four children (ages 14, 11, 8, and 4). Miriam began selling "pupusas" eight months ago. Before that, she managed a store by herself.

Miriam wants to invest in her business, so she will buy corn, oil, condiments, cheese, and other supplies that are necessary for her to make sales. This loan will help to improve her sales levels. Her goals are to have a larger business, obtain more customers, and earn more income.

loans.use: to buy corn, oil, condiments, cheese, and other supplies.

loans.name: Alimatu

texts.en:
Meet 34-year-old Alimatu from Waterloo, a neighborhood of Freetown, Sierra Leone. She is widowed with three children between the ages of 10 and 21, all of whom currently attend school. In 2008, Alimatu established her food container business: she sells cooking pots, saucepans, rubber buckets and dishes. Alimatu began her business because she needed a permanent source of income to support her family. She works at the business from 7:30 am until 7:00 pm, seven days per week. She says that the main challenges to her business are transportation and price fluctuations.
 
Alimatu requires a loan in order to buy more food containers such as cooking pots, saucepans, rubber buckets and dishes. She hopes that the extra income from this loan will allow her to educate her children. In the future, Alimatu plans to build a house. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy more food containers such as cooking pots, saucepans, rubber buckets and dishes.

loans.name: Teresia

texts.en:
Teresia sells curtains in Nakuru town and has been in this business for 11 years. She is 49 years old and a single mother to four children. Teresia plans to use the loan amount to purchase more curtain stock to sell in her business as the demand has increased a lot.

This will enable her to meet her clients' demands. With the anticipated profits, she plans to move to a permanent stall from which to sell the curtains.

In the future, Teresia hopes to expand her business by supplying the curtains at wholesale prices to other traders, thus earning more income and improving her family's living standards.

loans.use: To buy more curtain stock to sell

loans.name: Maisoon

texts.en:
Maisoon is a conservative woman so she is unwilling to upload her photo on the internet. The photo is of her husband.

Maisoon is 25 years old, a mother of 2 children, and she lives in Idon, Irbid, Jordan.

Maisoon is looking to have a loan of 400 JDs so she can expand her store and buy merchandise for it. Maisoon is under 30 years old so her loan is considered as a youth loan.

loans.use: to buy goods for her store

loans.name: Jawhara

texts.en:
Jawhara is 27 years old and married. She is a mother of three children. She lives in Al Nasser, Amman, Jordan.

Jawhara is looking to have a loan of 400 JD so she can expand her trading in blankets sales. She will buy more blankets in wholesale and sell them in retail.

Jawhara is under 30 years old so her loan is a youth loan.

loans.use: to buy blankets for trading purposes

loans.name: Eman

texts.en:
Eman is a conservative woman who is unwilling to upload her photo on the internet. The photo is of her husband.

Eman is 29 years old. She is a mother of three children and she lives in Al Russeifeh, Jordan.

Eman is looking to have a loan of 400 JD to buy new furniture and paint her home to make it more comfortable for her family.

Eman is under 30 years old, so her loan is a youth loan

loans.use: to buy new furniture and paint her home

loans.name: Oyunchimeg

texts.en:
Oyunchimeg is 46 years old and lives with her husband in a ger (a Mongolian yurt) in Darhan-uul province, Mongolia. Her husband is a carpenter and her two kids live independently. She started her garment retailing business in 2001 by renting an outdoor counter. Her garments are high quality and affordable. 

Now that her children live independently, she has time to expand her business. Oyunchimeg is planning to have her own counter. She's requesting a loan of 2,000,000 MNT to buy summer garments for her business. She is a smart hard-working woman who says, "Now that I finally have time to spare, I want to make the most of it."

loans.use: To buy summer garments

loans.name: Tabitha

texts.en:
Tabitha is 23 years old. She is married to Geoffrey and together they have two children. She sells clothes and has been in this business for the past two years.

This is her first loan from KADET LTD. Tabitha was brought to KADET LTD by a staff member. She will use the loan amount to purchase stock of new clothes to sell in her business.

Tabitha hopes to own a boutique in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase stock of new clothes to sell.

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter is 36 years old and is married with three children. He sells cereals and has been in this business for the past six years.

This is his first loan. Peter was introduced to KADET LTD by a staff member. He will use the loan amount to purchase stock of maize, beans and green grams (mung beans) to sell.

He hopes to venture into the real estate business.

loans.use: to purchase more stock of maize, beans and green grams (mung beans) to sell.

loans.name: Bassama Organisation Group

texts.en:
Meet the members of the “Bassama Organisation” group from Koidu, a city in eastern Sierra Leone. They are all local entrepreneurs who have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva.org, to apply for a loan of SLL 500,000 Sierra Leonean Leones for each member of the group. With the help of this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and consequently improve their living conditions. 

Sarah, aged 40, is the leader of this group. She is married to a civil servant and they have four children. Sarah has been a businesswoman for many years now: she sells market food – palm oil, margi (which is used to give sauce a sweet taste), salt, pepper, fish, etc. With her share of this loan, she will buy the above-mentioned items at wholesale prices to add to her business. 

(Also included in the photo is loan officer, Edward A Ndoinjeh, handing over the loan to the borrowers.)

loans.use: to buy palm oil, margi, salt, pepper, fish, etc. at wholesale prices to add to her business

loans.name: Ne'ameh

texts.en:
Ne'ameh is 40 years old and married. She is a mother of five children. She lives in Al Zarqa, Jordan.
Ne'ameh is looking to have a loan of 600 JD so she can expand her work in clothing sales to increase her income. She will buy more quantities of clothing for trading.

loans.use: to buy clothes to sell

loans.name: Fatema

texts.en:
Fatema is 21 years old and single. She lives in Al Salt, Jordan.

Fatema is looking to have a loan of 1,000 JD so she can sell various quantities of cosmetics.

Fatema is under 30 years old so her loan is a youth loan.

loans.use: to buy cosmetics to sell

loans.name: Hob Alwtn Group

texts.en:
This group is called Hob Alwtn. It consists of four members: Salma, Shwayh, Amnh and Fatima. They are ladies who are responsible for their families. Their community is a rural area surrounded by fields where they make Yemeni bread. They have many clients, mostly women. 

Salma is 28 years old. She is the coordinator of her group. (She is the second woman from the left side on the photo). She is a divorced woman and has one daughter. In the beginning, she learned how to make bread from her neighbors, then continued her activity. It is the main source of income so that she can help raise her daughter and give her a good education.   

Salma's most important challenges are to work hard to gain extra income and to improve her business structure. She is receiving a youth loan of 30,000 YER from AMB to buy bread materials like flour, salt, yeast and baking soda for her business.

In the future, she would like to expand her business to improve her living conditions.

loans.use: to buy bread ingredients like flour, salt, yeast and baking soda for her business.

loans.name: Abatarambirwa Group

texts.fr:
Safiya fait partie du groupe Abatarambirwa et  habite à  Ngozi. Elle a 32 ans et est mariée à Ramazani,  un commerçant des habits. Ensemble ils ont 4 enfants, âgé de 6 à 15 ans, tous  étudient à l’école primaire.

Elle est  commerçante d’huile de palme depuis 4 ans. 

Elle est à son neuvième  crédit à Turame. Avec le crédit KIVA qu’elle obtient, elle  va  augmenter son capital et acheter  beaucoup de bidons d’huile de palme, à revendre, pour gagner plus. 

Dans les prochaines  années, elle voudrait chercher le raccordement de l’eau et de l’électricité de son domicile et acheter une autre parcelle.
texts.en:
Safiya is a member of the Abatarambirwa group, and she lives in  Ngozi. She is 32 years old, and is married to Ramazani, a clothing salesman. Together they have 4 children, aged from 6 to 15 years old - all attending primary school. 

She has been trading palm oil for 4 years. 

This is her ninth loan with Turame. With the KIVA loan she is seeking, she will increase her working capital by buying a large quantity of containers of palm oil to resell, in order to increase her income.

In the coming years, she would like to have water and electricity connected to her home, and to buy an additional plot of land.

loans.use: to increase her working capital - buying a large quantity of containers of palm oil to resell.

loans.name: Abdu

texts.en: This is Abdu, 33, a resident of Taiz, Yemen. He is married with three children. He manages his own household while operating the business. At this time, he is working hard to continually provide income for his everyday expenses. He has operated a grocery store for two years. He has been able to expand his business and his regular customers are his neighbors and the local community. To help him continue operations of his business, he is requesting a loan of 100,000 YER from AMB to buy grocery items such as eggs, soaps, soft drinks, etc. This loan will enable him to expand his product inventory. He expects a boost in his business income. He hopes to open another store to improve his living conditions.

loans.use: to buy grocery items such as eggs, soap, soft drinks, etc for his business

loans.name: Dolores María

texts.es:
EL Banco Divino Niño Jesús se reúne cada quince días en el Cantón Jipijapa, cantón conocido con el nombre de la sultana del café por los extensos cultivos de café el cual tiene un sabor incomparable, por su gastronomía y por la calidez de su gente. 

En este lugar conocimos a la señora Dolores, tiene 47 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tienen cinco hijos, 4 de mayores de edad y una de 14 años la misma que  estudia en colegio y es quien aun vive con ella. Su esposo es comerciante.

Ella con la intención de ayudar a su esposo realiza el crédito para que él lo utilice en su negocio, él se dedica a la venta de ropa de todo tipo, nos cuenta nuestra amiga que él se desplaza a los campos con la finalidad de vender sus productos. Trabaja todos los días desde las 8h00  hasta las 16h00 que regresa a su hogar, vende al contado y también deja a crédito  a sus clientes más conocidos y confiables a los mismos que les cobra cada 8 días. Su mercadería  la va a comprar a  Guayaquil cada quince días o cuando necesite. Tiene 7 años que se dedica a esta actividad y le va muy bien, gracias a esto su familia sale adelante.

Este crédito lo va emplear en comprar más mercadería como: pantalones, blusas, camisetas y ropa de niños. Está desde el inicio en el Banco Comunal y le gusta por la oportunidad que le dan para poder salir adelante junto a su familia. 

Su sueño es tener un local para que su esposo no tenga que salir tan lejos a realizar sus ventas.
texts.en:
The Communal Bank "Divino Niño Jesús" (Divine Christ Child) meets every 15 days in the canton of Jipijapa, which is known by its nickname "The Sultana of Coffee" because of its extensive coffee crop that has an incomparable flavor. This area is also known for its food and the warmth of its people.

It is in this place that one can meet Sra. Dolores. She is 47 years old, married, and has five children. Four of them are grown and the youngest is 14 years old, attends high school, and lives with her. Her husband is a merchant.

Dolores intends to help her husband, so she will use this loan for his business. He sells clothing of all types. Dolores says that her husband travels to the countryside to sell his products. He works every day from 8am to 4pm and then returns home. Her husband sells his products for cash, but he also extends credit. His customers are well-known and trustworthy, so he is able to collect payments every eight days. The merchandise is purchased in Guayaquil every 15 days or as needed. Her husband has been in business for seven years and has done very well. As a result, their family has been able to get ahead.

This loan will be used to buy more merchandise, such as trousers, blouses, T-shirts, and children's clothing. Dolores has been with her Communal Bank from the beginning and enjoys being a member because it has given her the opportunity to move forward with her family. Her dream is to own a shop with her husband so that he does not have to travel far in order to generate sales.

loans.use: to buy trousers, blouses, T-shirts, and children's clothing.

loans.name: Mahmoud

texts.en: Mahmoud is a 25-year-old married man, and he lives with his wife. Four years ago Mahmoud opened his own cell phone store in Gaza. He hopes to get this youth loan in order to buy new phones for his store. He hopes that this loan will improve his business and increase his income.

loans.use: to buy new phones for his store.

loans.name: Muntaser

texts.en: Muntaser is 22 years old and lives in Gaza. He owns a paint shop where he sells paint and paint tools, and his dream is to expand his business and become well-known. He is requesting a youth loan for $2,500 from Ryada to buy a motorized rickshaw, which will allow him to deliver his orders faster and expand his business. Muntser hopes to use the additional profits he earns to improve his living conditions.

loans.use: to buy a motorized rickshaw to deliver his products to customers.

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en: Ahmad is 24 years old and lives in Gaza. He owns a hair-cutting salon which he opened on January 1, 2010. He hopes to get this youth loan in order to buy supplies for his salon so that he can continue his work, start a family and provide well for his future wife and children.

loans.use: to buy supplies for his hair-cutting salon.

loans.name: Falasteen

texts.en:
Falasteen is a conservative person who prefers not to have her photo published online, so her husband Ahmad appears in her Kiva profile photo, pictured in his workshop.

Falasteen is a 24-year-old young woman. She is married to Ahmad and they don't have any children yet. For the past two years, Falasteen's husband has been opening a workshop for repairing computers and extending ADSL to homes and institutions, which has been a profitable project, but also needs more support to cover the family's needs.

Falasteen is requesting a 2,000 USD youth loan from FATEN to help her husband cover the costs of purchasing a new repair kit and to buy wire to extend ADSL. This will increase the size of his business and improve the service provided to his customers and thus improve the family's income.

loans.use: To purchase a new repair kit and to buy wire to extend ADSL.

loans.name: Zubidh

texts.en: Zubidh is 50 years old, married and has four children who live together in Hadramout, Yemen. She started her business selling medicinal herbs a long time ago. Then she opened a store in the same field. She took out a loan of 100,000 YER from AMB to buy additional medicinal herbs in order to offer better service to her clients. She hopes to enroll her children in schools.

loans.use: to buy additional medicinal herbs to sell

loans.name: Lorena

texts.es: Lorena vive en Quinindé, Ecuador con hermosas tradiciones vivas y un clima muy tropical donde se pueden encontrar vastas plantaciones de palma africana. La mayor parte de la gente se concentra en la ciudad de Quinindé cerca de la carretera que cruza de Quito a Santo Domingo y donde pueden parar para tomar un descanso, un excelente lugar para comerciar y donde se pueden encontrar restaurantes, cafés, entre otros para descansar. Lorena una mujer de 30 años, con una nena de 3 años, comenzó como vendedora ambulante de cosméticos hace 3 años y ha tenido buenos resultados. Ella trabaja sola y aprendió el negocio de su hermana quien tomó la iniciativa. Lorena trabaja alrededor de 6 horas diarias en el negocio y espera que con una inversión más alta pueda también incrementar sus ventas para poder seguir con sus metas. Uno de sus sueños es conseguir un título profesional para seguir creciendo como persona y darle a su hija el mejor de los ejemplos a seguir como lo ha hecho hasta ahora. Con la inversión en el negocio, esperemos que se cumplan todas las metas de Lorena y le deseamos mucho éxito.
texts.en:
Lorena lives in Quinindé, Ecuador, which is known for its beautiful traditions and a tropical climate where one can find vast plantations of African palms. Most of the people who reside in the city of Quinindé live near the highway that runs from Quito to Santo Domingo. This place is a rest stop for those who are tired, so it is an excellent spot for merchants to sell and set up restaurants, cafés, and other places where people can relax.

Lorena is a 30-year-old woman who has a little girl who is three years old. She started out three years ago as a street merchant selling cosmetics and achieved good results. Lorena works alone, but she learned the business from her sister who took the initiative. She works in her business approximately six hours each day and hopes that a bigger investment will increase her sales so that she can continue to reach her goals. One of her dreams to obtain a professional degree so that she can continue growing as a person and be a good role model for her daughter just as she has done so far.

With this investment in her business, Fundacion Alternativa hopes that Lorena will reach all of her goals and wishes her much success.

loans.use: to buy cosmetics.

loans.name: Suhair

texts.en:
Suhair is a conservative person who prefers not to have her photo published online, so her husband Hussni appears in her Kiva profile photo. This picture was taken in his store, where he sells vehicles and spare parts.

Suhair is a 37-year-old woman. She is married to Hussni and a mother to four sons. Her husband Hussni has been operating a store for selling spare auto parts, which is the only source of income to the family and a profitable project, but also not enough to cover all the costs and the family's needs.

Suhair is requesting a loan of $2000 to help her husband cover the costs of purchasing necessary spare auto parts to resell. This will provide Suhair's husband with a varied collection of spare parts, which will help to increase sales and improve the family's income.

loans.use: To help her husband purchase necessary spare auto parts to resell and improve the family's income.

loans.name: Bilal

texts.en:
Bilal is a 27-year-old young man. He is married, with no children yet. For the past four years, Bilal has been operating a phone accessories store, which is his only source of income and has become a profitable project, but also not enough to cover all of his costs.

Bilal is requesting a youth loan to help him cover the costs of purchasing a new collection of phone accessories to resell. This will offer Bilal's customers a new selection to choose from, and buy, which will lead to increased sales and improve the family's income.

Bilal is pictured inside his store. 


About this loan product:
FATEN offers loans that are customized for Muslim borrowers. A key principle of Islam is the prohibition of charging interest on a loan. This prohibition is based on the belief that money is only a medium of exchange and has no value in itself. In order to offer loans in a manner that is consistent with borrowers' values, FATEN charges 0% interest on this loan. However, FATEN does charge a servicing fee to cover its costs. The loan amount you see listed on Kiva includes both the principal loan and the loan servicing fees. As with all Kiva loans, you should expect to have your funds returned to you according to this loan’s repayment schedule. For more information on lending in the Muslim world, please click here.

loans.use: To purchase a new collection of phone accessories to resell.

loans.name: Haytham

texts.en:
Haytham is a 25-year-old young man, he is married with no children yet.
For the past three years, Haytham has been opening a grocery store, which is the only source of income to him and a profitable project, but also not enough to cover all the costs.
Haytham is requesting a USD youth loan from FATEN to help him cover the costs of purchasing more groceries to resell such as: rice, milk, canned food. This will offer to Haytham collection of groceries that customers often request and buy, which will increase sales and improve the family's income.
Haytham is photographed in his store.


About this loan product:
FATEN offers loans that are customized for Muslim borrowers. A key principle of Islam is the prohibition of charging interest on a loan. This prohibition is based on the belief that money is only a medium of exchange and has no value in itself. In order to offer loans in a manner that is consistent with borrowers' values, FATEN charges 0% interest on this loan. However, FATEN does charge a servicing fee to cover its costs. The loan amount you see listed on Kiva includes both the principal loan and the loan servicing fees. As with all Kiva loans, you should expect to have your funds returned to you according to this loan’s repayment schedule. For more information on lending in the Muslim world, please click here.

loans.use: To purchase groceries for sale

loans.name: Samir

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. He is 59 years old, is married, and has two children who both work.

Samir has owned a food market since 2008, selling soft drinks, juice, cheese, frozen beef, chicken, fish, dairy products, and other groceries. He has sufficient experience in this field and a deep understanding of local customers, so he knows about their needs. He has a good reputation and he is well-known in the surrounding areas.

He is requesting a loan of $2400 in order to redecorate his market, install an overhang to provide shade, and to add more foodstuffs. He aims to gain more profits so he will have the opportunity to provide a better life for his family as a whole.

loans.use: redecorate his market, install an overhang to provide shade, and add more foodstuffs.

loans.name: Ra

texts.en: Ra, 26, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia. She has been involved in the agricultural business for more than ten years, has extensive experience and is successful in her career. She is involved in cassava cultivation.  She earns approximately USD 4 per day. Her husband is a tractor driver who runs a tilling service. He earns about USD 10 per day. Her children are still in her care. In order to improve her family’s livelihood, Ra is requesting a loan of USD 1200 to purchase more farmland to use for cultivating cassava. By doing so, she would earn more income to support the family.  In the future, she would like to expand her business and help her children get bachelor’s degrees.

loans.use: to purchase more farmland for cultivating cassava

loans.name: God Bless Group

texts.en:
Kumba is the leader of this group of entrepreneurs. Kumba was born in Koidu City, about thirty-five years ago. She is married to a monthly salaried worker and the couple has three children together who are attending primary and secondary schools. Kumba sells market food – palm-oil, salt, pepper, fish, etc. and has been doing this business for many years now.

With the help of this loan, Kumba and her group members will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and consequently improve on their living conditions. Kumba will use her share of the loan (500,000 SLL) to buy palm-oil, salt, pepper, fish, etc. in larger quantities to add to her business.

(Also included in the photo is loan officer Edward A Ndoinjeh, handing over the loan to the borrowers).

loans.use: to buy palm-oil, salt, pepper, fish, etc. in larger quantities to add to her business.

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter is thirty-one years old and is married with two  children. He is a mechanic. He has been in this business for eleven years now and gets a monthly income of KES 40000.

This will be his second loan from KADET LTD. He plans to use the entire loan to purchase a drilling and pressing machine. With the profit he wants to expand the workshop. In future he wants to own a big workshop.

loans.use: to purchase a drilling and pressing machine.

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Nancy has been in the clothes-selling business in Nakuru town, Kenya, for the last four years. She is 35 years old and married to Raymond and they have three children.

She was introduced to KADET LTD by one of her friends, and this will be her second loan. She plans to use the loan amount to pay school fees for her children.

In the future, she plans to open a big boutique and sell all kinds of clothes, thereby making more income and improving her family's living standards. From the income she also hopes to build a house for her family.

loans.use: to pay  school  fees.

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James is thirty-one years old and married with two  children. He sells electronics and he has been in this business for seven years now and earns a monthly income of KES. 30,000.

This will be his second loan from KADET LTD. He plans to use the entire loan to purchase more stock of spare parts for  radios. In future he wants to sell from his own shop.

loans.use: to purchase more stock of spare parts for radios.

loans.name: Ciapha M.

texts.en: Ciapha lives in Kakata Town. He is 32 years old, single, and has a three-year-old child who is in school and lives at home. He stopped his education in the 10th grade. For 11 years now, he has been running a drug store in his community. He makes a lot of profit and has more customers. He started this business with LRD 21,600. He is requesting a loan to purchase more drugs likes, cough syrup,paracetamol(fever reducer), ibuprofen(for aches) blood tonic, alcohol, convex, others items and drugs for his business. His plan is to expand his business even more.

loans.use: to purchase more drugs likes, cough syrup, paracetamol (fever reducer), ibuprofen (for aches) blood tonic, alcohol, convex, others items and drugs for his business

loans.name: Jerryline

texts.en: Jerryline lives in the Airport community. She is  29 years old, single, and has an eight year old child that is in school.  For the past ten  years Jerryline has been operating a shop (booth) where she sells phone credit cards, and phone chargers. Jerryline is requesting a loan to purchase more phone credit cards ,and electronic accessories (chargers for phones) for her business. She plans is to build a house in the future.

loans.use: to purchase more phone credit cards, and electronic accessories (chargers for phones) for her business

loans.name: Sallay

texts.en:
Meet 39-year-old Sallay from Grassfied eastern area in Freetown, Sierra Leone. She is married with 1 child ages 23 years. Sallay's child is currently in university. In 2007, Sallay established her general merchandise business. She began her business because she wanted to improve her life and be self independent. She works at the business 6 days per week and 10 hours a day. She says that the major problems to her business are price fluctuation and the low purchase power of customers. 
 
Sally requires a loan of Le 5,000,000 in order to buy more soft drinks, cement, oil, packet water, bag flour and sugar. She hopes that the extra income from this loan will allow her to educate her daughter. In the future, Sally plans to increase her savings and building a big house. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy more soft drinks, cement, oil, packet water, bag flour and sugar.

loans.name: Marie   J

texts.en:
This is 43-year-old Marie from Tengbeh town in the western area of Freetown, Sierra Leone.  She is married and has four children between the ages of 11 and 18 years.  Her children currently attend school. 

Marie runs a bar and a restaurant where she sells crate drinks, food and mobile phones.  She has been running this business for 15 years.  She works at the business seven days per week, 11 hours a day.  She also earns income from her husband.  She says that the main challenge to her business is price inflation.

Marie has requested a loan in order to buy more assorted drinks, foodstuffs and mobile phones.  The extra income from this loan will allow her to change her standard of living and educate her children.  In the future, she plans to open an outlet. 

She appreciates your support.

loans.use: to buy more assorted drinks, foodstuffs and mobile phone.

loans.name: Mujeres Emprendedoras  (Jipijapa) Group

texts.es:
EL Banco Comunal Mujeres Emprendedoras se reúne cada quince días en el Cantón Jipijapa, cantón conocido con el nombre de la sultana del café por los extensos cultivos de café el cual tiene un sabor incomparable, por su gastronomía y por la calidez de su gente.
 
Este es un grupo de personas que decidieron unirse y formar este Banco Comunal que les ha servido de mucho en todo este tiempo que han estado en el grupo.  Se dedican a diversas actividades tales como comercio, servicios, venta de comidas entre otras actividades.

En este lugar conocimos a la señora Yessica, tiene 29 años de edad, está separada y de esta relación tienen una niña de 9 años de edad, la misma que estudia en escuela.Vive en casa de sus padres.

Ella para salir adelante y para que a su hija no le falte nada, hace 3 años atrás junto lo poco que tenia y solicito un crédito en el banco comunal y con esto instalo un pequeño negocio, ella tiene una tienda de comestibles en la casa de sus padres, allí vende todo tipo de productos de primera necesidad, trabaja todos los días desde las 6h00 hasta las 20h00 y a veces hasta más tarde, nos cuenta que en temporadas también se dedica a la venta de ropa de todo tipo y que esto lo hace puerta a puerta, en las temporadas que vende.
 
Este crédito lo va a emplear en surtir mas su tienda, va a comprar arroz, azúcar, aceite, detergentes, entre otros productos de primera necesidad. Está en el Banco Comunal desde el inicio, es la tesorera del grupo y le gusta porque gracias al crédito instalo su negocio que hoy le permite ganarse la vida.
 
Sus metas son seguir adelante y que a su hija nunca le falte nada ya que por ello lucha todos los días.

La foto pequeña es de dos socias que no pudieron estar presentes cuando se tomó la foto del grupo.
texts.en:
The Mujeres Emprendedoras communal bank meets every two weeks in Jipijapa Canton, a canton known as "La Sultana del Café" for its extensive fields of incomparably flavored coffee, its cuisine, and the warmth of its people.

This is a group of people who decided to get together and form this communal bank, which has served them well in all the time they have been in the group.  They work in various activities, such as trade, service, and food sales, among others.

Here we met Yessica.  She is 29 years old and separated, and from this relationship they have a 9-year-old girl who attends school.  She lives in her parents' house.

To get ahead and so her daughter does not need anything, three years ago Yessica saved up what little she had and requested a loan in the communal bank to set up a small business.  She has a grocery store in her parents' house where she sells all types of staples.  She works every day from 6 a.m. until 8 p.m., and sometimes later.  She tells us that in season she also sells all types of clothing, which she does door-to-door in the seasons in which she sells. 

She is going to use this loan to stock her store.  She is going to buy rice, sugar, oil, and detergent, among other staple items.

She has been in the communal bank since the beginning.  She is the treasurer of the group and she likes it because thanks to the loan she set up her business, which today allows her to make a living.  Her goals are to get ahead and for her daughter never to need anything, because she struggles for her every day.

The small photo is of two members who were not able to be there when the group photo was taken.

loans.use: to buy rice, sugar, oil, detergent, and other staple items.

loans.name: Adiza

texts.en:
Adiza is single and  sells waakye (rice and beans cooked together). She serves it with gari, macroni, meat and fish stew.  Adiza has been selling waakye for 3 years now. She uses her income to pay her accomodations bill.  

Adiza need this loan to purchase bags of rice, beans and other ingredient for the preparation of her waakye for sale. With the new profit, Adiza will expand her business.

loans.use: buy ingredients to make food to sell

loans.name: Efua

texts.en: Efua cooks banku (a dish made from corn dough) for sale; she serves it with fried fish, pepper and tomato sauce at Adum Enyinase, near Elmina. She is a widow and has four children. Efua has done this for six years. She uses her income to feed her family and pay her accomodation bills. Her loan will be used to purchase bags of maize and fish which she uses in preparing her banku for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to mount a stall for the sale of her cooked banku and fish.

loans.use: to purchase maize and fish which she uses in preparing her banku for sale

loans.name: Mary's Group

texts.en:
Mary's group is comprised of 3 hard-working women. Mary is 21 years old, single, and has two children, one of whom attends school. She lives in the town of Bulenga in the Kampala west region of Uganda. For the past year, Mary has been working hard to manage her small business, which sells pigs. 

To help expand her business, Mary is requesting a loan for 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda, which she will use to buy more pigs and feeds. This loan help Mary to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her son. In the future, she hopes to be able to own a retail shop. 

Mary is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training. The ELA program has increased Mary's future prospects by helping her to improve her lifestyle.

loans.use: to buy more pigs and feeds.

loans.name: Abibatu

texts.en:
This is 32-year-old Abibatu from Waterloo, a neighborhood in Freetown, Sierra Leone. She is married to a businessman, and she has a 16-year-old child. Abibatu is a very hardworking woman. She began this business because she did not go to school and grew up in the village. Local foodstuff sales is the business she understands best. 

Abibatu runs a local foodstuff business. She sells beans, groundnuts, rice, corn, and pepper. She has been running this business for 15 years. She works at the business 7 days per week and 12 hours per day. She does not have any source of income except her business. She says that the main challenge for her business is transportation to move the goods from the province to Waterloo.

Abibatu has requested a Le 6000000 loan through BRAC to buy more local foodstuff such as beans, groundnuts, rice, corn, and pepper. The extra income from this loan will allow her to educate her child. In the future, she plans to expand her business and build more stores. She appreciates your support.

loans.use: To buy more local foodstuff such as beans, groundnuts, rice, corn, and pepper.

loans.name: Jocob

texts.en:
Jocob is 34 years old, married with 2 children. He sells car spare parts to earn a living. He has been in the business for 4 years and describes his business environment as favorable because there is limited competition. To earn extra income he runs a retail shop. 

Since he joined Faulu Kenya, he has been able to save his income and hopes to expand his business in the future. He has applied for 100,000 Kenya Shillings to buy car spare parts to sell.

loans.use: To buy automobile spare parts for sale.

loans.name: Julius

texts.en:
Julius is 31 years old and married with two children. He runs a grocery store to earn a living. He has been in the business for six years and has employed one person. He describes his business environment as competitive because many people do the same business. 

Since he joined Faulu Kenya, he has been able to save his income and hopes to expand his business in the future. He has applied for a 60,000 Kenya Shillings loan to buy onions, potatoes, tomatoes and bananas to sell.

loans.use: To buy onions, potatoes, tomatoes and bananas to sell.

loans.name: Esi

texts.en: Esi  lives together with her husband and 3 children at Breman near Elmina. Esi sells 'gari'  and maize which she has done for 15 years now. She uses her income to assist her husband in paying their children’s school fees.  Esi will use her loan to purchase bags of 'gari' and maize to sell. With the new profit she will expand her business.

loans.use: purchase bags of 'gari' (cassava couscous) and maize to sell.

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en:
Comfort sells waakye (rice and beans cooked together). She serves it with gari, macaroni, meat and fish stew. Comfort has been selling waakye for 2 years now. She is married. Her husband is a farmer. She uses her income to support her husband to pay her accommodation bill. 

Comfort needs this loan to purchase bags of rice, beans and other ingredients for the preparation of her waakye. With the new profit, Comfort will expand her business.

loans.use: purchase bags of rice, beans and other ingredients for the preparation of her waakye for sale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase wood to sell

loans.name: Efua

texts.en:
Efua is a small trader selling footwear, which she has done for 2 years. She lives in Asebu, near Takoridi. Efua is married, and has 2 children. She uses her income to support her husband in paying their accommodation bills. 

Efua will use her loan to purchase footwear to sell. With the additional profit from her expanded business, she wishes to build a shop in which to sell her footwear.

loans.use: to purchase footwear to sell

loans.name: Ama

texts.en: Ama is a small-scale trader. She sells cosmetics at Asebu near Cape Coast. She has been selling cosmetics for 4 years. She is married with 3 children. Her husband is a teacher. She uses her income to assist her husband to feed and clothe her children and pay their school fees. Ama will use her loan to purchase more cosmetics to sell. She hopes to use the new profits to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more cosmetics to sell

loans.name: Ama

texts.en: Ama sells locally made soap and saucepans at Asebu near Cape Coast. She has been selling this type of soap for 8 years now. She is a single parent  and has 4 children. She uses her income to provide for her family. Ama will use her loan to purchase saucepans to sell and raw materials to produce her soap for sale. With the new profit, Ama will expand her business.

loans.use: to buy raw materials to produce her soap for sale and to purchase saucepans to resell

loans.name: Philip

texts.en: Philip has requested for fourth loan worth KES 50,000 from KADET Ltd. to purchase a plying machine,and more timber for carpentry work. The profit he earns will aid him to expand his workshop. This is his fourth loan. His dream is to prosper in his business.

loans.use: To buy  a plying machine and more timber  for carpentry work.

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John is a thirty-nine-year-old man; he is married and has four children. He runs a dairy farming business in Zambezi.  He has been in the business for six years now and gets a monthly income of forty thousand shillings.


This will be John fifth loan from KADET LTD, he plans to use the entire loan to  purchase a cow and build a dairy shed. 

With the profit that he will get, he wants to educate his children. In future he wants to expand the business by  supplying milk to various institutions.

loans.use: To purchase a cow and build a dairy shed

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To construct a dairy unit and buy poultry birds.

loans.name: Francis

texts.en:
Francis is 26 years old and married with one child. He has been selling fish for four years to earn a living. He has employed two people to assist him in the business.  

Francis has grown his business through the financial support of Faulu Kenya. He used his previous loan to buy more fish. This enabled him to increase his sales and profits, which brought him additional income.

Francis hopes to grow his business into a wholesale business in the future. He has requested another loan of 50,000 KES to buy fish.

loans.use: To buy fish.

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
Virginia is 62 years old. She is married and has four children, all of whom are grownups. She is a poultry farmer and has been in this business for the past 10 years.

This is Virginia's third loan from KADET LTD. She paid her previous loans well and on time. She will use the loan amount to purchase chicks for rearing.

She hopes to be a well-known poultry farmer in her area. She also hopes to grow her business and start supplying chicken to the hotels in her area.

loans.use: to purchase chicks for rearing and then to sell later at a profit.

loans.name: Ita

texts.en:
Ita is 30 years old, married, and blessed with six children that he supports. He has been in the business of selling animals for the past 10 years, earning a monthly income of KES 40,000. 

He is borrowing a loan of KES 10,000 from KADET LTD, which he will use to buy more sheep for rearing and resale later.

He plans to use the anticipated profits to reinvest in order to expand and diversify his business. His future dream is to improve his living standards.

loans.use: to purchase sheep to sell

loans.name: Erick

texts.en:
Erick is 24 years old single man from Kakamega county in western Kenya.

Erick operates a brick backing business, which he has been running for the past three years. He makes a monthly income of KES 5,000. He is taking his first loan from KADET LTD, which he will use to buy firewood for burning bricks.

He will use the anticipated profits to burn more bricks. His dream is to live comfortably.

loans.use: To buy firewood for burning bricks.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther is married and has three children. She owns a hotel (restaurant) in Emali town. She has been in the business for nine years now and gets a monthly income of eight thousand shillings.

This will be her first loan from KADET. She plans to use the entire loan to purchase more stocks as wheat flour, rice, beans and maize flour for making food for sale to her customers. In the future she wants to be able to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more stocks for sale, such as wheat flour, rice, beans and maize flour.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy stock of textile materials.

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
Virginia is 21 years old and single. She is a tailor and has been in the business for the past six years. She gets a monthly income of KES 9,000 from the business.

This is her first loan from KADET LTD. She was introduced to KADET by another client. She will use the loan to purchase clothing material for sewing.

She hopes to own a boutique in the near future.

loans.use: purchase clothing material

loans.name: Samson

texts.en:
Samson is fifty years old. He is married with nine children. He operates a "posho" (cornmeal) mill and also has a timber yard which is his secondary business. He has been in the business for the past twenty-one years.

This is his second loan from  KADET LTD. He will use the loan amount to purchase cereals and also timber for his timber yard business.

He hopes to own residential houses in the near future and be a landlord.

loans.use: to purchase cereals, especially dry maize, and also timber

loans.name: Mika

texts.en:
Mika paid his previous loan well and in time. He is widowed with three children. Mika sells ground nuts and he is a mechanic in Grogan. He has been in the business for 13 years now.

This will be his second loan from KADET LTD. He plans to use the entire loan to buy tools for his mechanic work and more groundnuts to sell to his customers. 

The anticipated profits will be used to educate his children. In the future, he wants to buy a plot in Nairobi.

loans.use: to purchase tools and   more  groundnuts.

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice has been in the shoe selling business in Nakuru town for the last two years. She is 36 years old, married to Dennis who is a journalist, and they have been blessed with three children.

This will be her first loan and she plans to use it to buy more shoes to sell in her business.This includes both open and closed shoes for men and women as well as children. 


In the future, Alice hopes to grow her business and make more income hence buy a plot of land and build a house for her family.

loans.use: To buy more  stock of shoes for sale.

loans.name: Francis

texts.en:
Francis is 56 years old. He is married to Sarah and together they have eight children. He operates a quarry site whereby he mines stones and sell to his customers and has been in the business for the past 28 years.

This is his second loan from KADET LTD. He paid his previous loan well and in good time. He will use the requested loan to expand his business by purchasing another quarry site.

He hopes to own a large quarry and provide stones to most builders in his area.

loans.use: To buy more stones to add to his stock.

loans.name: Julia

texts.en:
Julia is thirty two years old married lady with six children. She sells suits and has been in the business for three years now and gets a monthly income of twenty six thousand shillings. 


This will be her first loan with KADET LTD, she plans to use the entire loan to buy more suits. In future she wants to buy a piece of land and have a good future.

loans.use: to buy more suits

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John is 25 years and is married to Mariam. They have two children, who are in school.

John is a farmer and has been involved in farming activity for the past two years. He has applied for his first loan from KADET Ltd., to enable him to buy seedlings and fertilizers to use in his farm.

He hopes to expand his farm in the future.

loans.use: To buy seedlings and fertilizers.

loans.name: Simion

texts.en:
Simion is 41 years old, married and supports seven members of his family.  He has six children aged between five and 15 years old.  He owns a retail shop selling varieties of household goods and has been in operation for a period of 12 years, earning a monthly income of KES. 6,000.  

He is getting his first loan of KES. 25,000 from KADET LTD and intends to use this amount to purchase plastic cups, plastic plates, enamel cups and plates, torches and needles and thread.  


The earned profits will be used to pay school fees and plough back into the business.  He hopes to improve his family's living standard.

loans.use: to purchase plastic cups, plastic plates, enamel cups and plates, torches and needles and thread

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence is 35 years old and lives in the town of Kireka in Uganda. She is married and has five children, four of whom are currently in school. For the past three years, Florence has been working hard to manage her small shop, where she sells hardware. 

To help expand her business, Florence has requested a loan of 2,500,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to stock more items for resale. This will help Florence to generate greater profits and pay the school fees for her children. Florence hopes that in the future she will be able to open up another hardware business. 

Florence is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Florence who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans but have businesses that have grown too large for micro-loans.

loans.use: to stock more items for resale.

loans.name: Kinuthia

texts.en:
Kinuthia is 49 years and married to Jane. The couple has five children, all of whom are in school.

Kinuthia has a bicycle-repair business, which he has been doing for the past 14 years. He has applied for his first loan from KADET LTD to enable him buy spare parts to add to his stock.

He hopes to see his business expand in the near future.

loans.use: To buy spare parts to add to his stock for his bicycle-repair business.

loans.name: Doris

texts.en:
Doris is 44 years old. She runs a hardware shop to earn a living.  She has been in this business for 12 years. She has employed one person to assist her in her tasks.  

Doris has grown her business since she joined Faulu Kenya due to the training she received on business management skills.  

Doris hopes to open other business outlets in the future. She needs a loan of 100,000 KES to buy paint and lubricants for her hardware shop.

loans.use: To buy paint and lubricants for her hardware shop.

loans.name: Shandai Group

texts.en:
This is 47-year-old Loyce from Machipisa,a high-density suburb in Harare. She is married with four children, three still attending school. She is also taking care of her nephew and is responsible for the payment of his school fees. 

Loyce runs a manufacturing business of tailoring school uniforms. The business has been in operation for 13 years. She says the main challenges she faces are the erratic power supply and stiff competition. Loyce has requested a loan of $600 to buy rolls of cotton fabric and to pay for rent and rates to the local authority. She says the extra income generated as a result of this loan will allow her to improve the welfare of her family. In the future, Loyce plans to employ a great number of people to reduce unemployment.

loans.use: to buy fabric and pay rent and rates to the local authority

loans.name: Takashinga Women Group

texts.en: This is 52-year-old Mary.  She is from the capital of Zimbabwe, Harare, which means "he who does not sleep". She is married with two children. She also cares for two dependents. Mary runs a clothing business selling clothes and blankets. The business has been in operation for 20 years. She says the main challenge faced is stiff competition. Mary has requested a loan of $400 to buy clothes for resale. She says the extra income generated as a result of this loan will allow her to help in the family upkeep. In the future Mary plans to own a clothing shop.

loans.use: to buy clothes for resale

loans.name: Hope Group

texts.en:
Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), a partner of Kiva.org in Makeni, Northern Sierra Leone, is very pleased to present to you members of the “Hope” group. These are small-scale entrepreneurs who have come to SMT/Kiva lenders to seek a loan of 500,000 Sierra Leonean Leones  for each in the group in order to invest in their respective businesses.
 
Fatmata is the leader of this group. Fatmata is forty years old, she is married to a trader, and the couple has one child. Fatmata has been doing business for twenty years now. She is currently selling dried fish.  With the help of this loan, she will invest in her business by buying baskets full of dried fish to add to her current stock.

loans.use: to buy baskets full of dried fish to add to her current stock

loans.name: Amunafa Group

texts.en:
In the photo are members of the “Amunafa” group. They are small-scale businesswomen based in Kenema, a city in eastern Sierra Leone. This is the first loan these entrepreneurs are accessing from SMT/Kiva lenders.
